title: Tensions in ties with China the 'new normal': DFAT chief
text:
"Enduring differences" in the relationship with China are the "new normal", the head of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has conceded, amid ongoing tensions between Canberra and Beijing.

DFAT secretary Frances Adamson also said Australia had urged Chinese officials as well as pro-democracy activists to show restraint after months of protests in Hong Kong.

DFAT secretary Frances Adamson says both Australia and China will have to work hard on managing their relationship. Dominic Lorrimer

Appearing before Senate estimates on Thursday, she said China and Australia acknowledged there were continued opportunities in the relationship but differences would need to be skilfully handled.

"Those differences have been well publicised, not always accurately, but they exist and I think there is no point in us at all pretending they are not there," Ms Adamson said.

"In fact I think if we were to characterise our current relationship with China and the relationship going forward, it will be a relationship where we will need on both sides to work quite hard to manage what I really think will be enduring differences.
description: Alongside 'continued opportunities', DFAT chief Frances Adamson expects 'enduring differences' between Australia and China based on their divergent political systems and values.
